header.title: Occult Sciences: Sketches of the Traditions and Superstitions of Past Times, and the Marvels of the Present Day
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Magic, Divination, Spiritism, Mythology, Philosophy of Mind

central_thesis: This compendium offers a historical and descriptive account of Occult Sciences and related beliefs, exploring the evolution of various traditions, from ancient mythologies and philosophies to later superstitious practices. It aims to connect these phenomena to underlying principles of spiritual power, divine influence, and the interaction between the material and spiritual worlds, often bridging historical narrative with attempts at scientific or philosophical explanation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part I: The Belief in Supernatural Beings
structure_content.summary: This section categorizes and describes various supernatural entities such as Fairies, Elves, Familiars, Banshees, Genii, Daemons, the Devil, Incubi, Vampires, Goblins, Apparitions, and Angels. It delves into their historical origins, characteristics, perceived powers, and interactions with humanity across different cultures and eras, often noting the evolution of beliefs from ancient systems to later popular superstitions.

This part details the mythological and religious conceptions of spiritual realms and the afterlife, including Paradise, Heaven, Hades, Hell, and Purgatory. It discusses historical interpretations, philosophical views, and cultural depictions of these locations, tracing their presence in ancient texts and traditions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part III: The Exercise of Occult Power
structure_content.summary: This is a core operative section, providing detailed descriptions of various magical practices and their underlying philosophies. It covers Augury, Oracles (Delphi, Jupiter Hammon, Dodonus, Trophonius, Egyptian), the practices of the Magi, the Cabiri and Ancient Mysteries, Witchcraft, Exorcism, Necromancy, Sorcery of the Middle Ages, Modern Spirit Manifestations, Fascination, Whispering and Snake Charming, Sympathy and Antipathy, and Mesmerism. The focus is on the mechanics and perceived effects of these practices.

This section explores internal psychological phenomena believed to be linked to the supernatural or altered states of consciousness. It includes detailed analyses of Dreams, Visions, 'Visions of the Dying,' and Trance and Catalepsy, discussing their interpretation across different historical and philosophical contexts, and occasionally attempting to differentiate them from purely physical causes.

A comprehensive overview of various divination methods, both 'natural' and 'artificial'. Specific practices covered include Astrology, Lithomancy, Scyphomancy, Hydromancy, Catoptromancy, Crystallomancy, Gastromancy, Onimancy, Coscinomancy, Alectromancy, Clidomancy, Dactylomancy, Cledonism, Onomancy, Arithmomancy, Axinomancy, Aleuromancy or Alphitomancy, Belomancy, Rhabdomancy, Sortilege, Extispicy, Ooscopy and Oomantia, Ornithomancy, Aeromancy, Meteoromancy, Pyromancy, Capnomancy, Cleromancy, Gyromancy, Myomancy, and The Teraphim, detailing their historical application and underlying principles.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part VI: Natural and Artificial Charms
structure_content.summary: This section focuses on objects and formulas believed to possess magical or protective properties. It describes 'The Spell,' 'Touching for the Evil' (royal touch), Talismans, Amulets and Characts, Precious Stones and Metals (and their astrological correspondences), and Rings (including Solomon's signet ring and Gyges' ring). It delves into the perceived virtues, methods of creation, and historical uses of these magical items.

key_concepts.definition: A broad category encompassing hidden knowledge and practices related to the supernatural, including various forms of magic, divination, and beliefs concerning spirits and metaphysical phenomena, often rooted in ancient traditions.

The power to charm, enchant, or bewitch, primarily through the eyes or gaze. It is described as a subtle, often destructive, influence that can be exercised by certain individuals or even animals, operating on physical and psychological levels.

A system positing the existence of a subtle, universal fluid that can be harnessed through human will, touch, and gaze to induce an altered state (somnambulism), promote healing, and unlock latent faculties such as clairvoyance and prevision. The book discusses its historical applications and underlying theories, comparing ancient magnetic practices with modern manifestations.

Divination ('manteia') by summoning the dead ('nekros'). It is understood as a practice of calling forth spirits of deceased persons, often involving specific rituals, offerings, and the use of blood, to gain knowledge of future events or hidden truths.

The art of foretelling future events. It is broadly divided into 'natural' divination (divine revelations, prophetic powers, significant dreams) and 'artificial' divination (attainable through diligent observation of external phenomena and various techniques, often relying on chance or symbolic interpretation).

Written or spoken formulas of words believed to possess magical efficacy. Their power is thought to stem from an intimate connection between words and the things they signify, capable of producing effects such as propitiation, displeasure, or subjection to the will of the caster.

Objects, typically stones or metals, engraved with astrological characters, mystical symbols, or divine names. They are consecrated at auspicious times and believed to possess innate virtues or astral spirit influences for protection, healing, or influencing events, acting as remedies against diseases, evil spirits, or for various purposes.

practical_system.description: The text describes various operative magical systems designed for divination, protection, healing, and control over spirits. These systems draw upon ancient traditions, incorporating ritualistic actions, specific objects, verbal formulas, and altered states of consciousness to harness perceived supernatural or subtle natural forces. The overarching principle is the belief in a coherent, interconnected universe where human will and specific techniques can influence hidden powers for desired outcomes.
tools: Necromancy: Sword, sacrificial animals (rams, ewes), libation vessels, blood, trench.
Exorcism: Holy water, charcoal, various fumigation substances (Sabinae, Hypericonis, etc.), pictures of demons, inscribed divine names.
Spells/Charms: Magical knife, inscribed shields, leaden plates with magic squares, anodyne necklaces, coral and bells, camphor, arsenic, quicksilver-filled quills, sun-baked toad.

Talismans: Sympathetic stones and metals (e.g., jasper, beryl, diamond, sapphire) engraved with astrological characters, Hebrew numeral letters, or divine names; phylacteries, mezuzoth, gold coins (e.g., 'golden angels').
Divination (specific): Sieves and tongs/shears (Coscinomancy), cocks, wheat grains, alphabet-marked circles (Alectromancy), rings, glass tumblers, marked tables (Dactylomancy).
Mesmerism: Lodestone (artificial magnet), human hands/fingers, gaze, personal will.
Oracles (Delphi): Tripod, sacred fountain (Castalia), laurel leaves, sacrificial victims.
rituals: Necromancy: Digging a trench, pouring libations (milk, wine, water, flour), offering sacrificial victims (rams, ewes), uttering loud polysyllabic names to summon demons, using a sword to control spirits near offerings.

Exorcism: Employing specific words, prayers, and ceremonies; using holy water, drawn images of demons, and inscribed divine/angelic names. Practices include 'Preexorcizationes' (confessions, postulations, protestations, concitations, interrogations) and 'ex Sanctis nominibus Dei' (invoking sacred names).

Spells: Chanting specific verses or tunes (e.g., to ensure success in veterinary operations), using a written or spoken formula of words to produce a desired magical effect, often aided by symbolic actions like passing through a split oak plank.

Mesmerism/Animal Magnetism: Performing physical passes and frictions with hands/thumbs, maintaining a fixed gaze, and concentrating the will to induce a somnambulistic state, heal illnesses, and access clairvoyant abilities.

Divination (e.g., Alectromancy, Dactylomancy): Setting up a circle with alphabet letters and observing a cock peck grains (Alectromancy); suspending a ring by a thread/hair over a marked table or glass and observing its movements (Dactylomancy).

Augury: Observing celestial phenomena (thunder, lightning), flight and notes of birds, or behavior of animals (e.g., wolves, bees, chickens) to interpret omens. Requires careful observation and knowledge of specific interpretations.

Charms/Amulets/Talismans: Carrying or wearing specific objects (stones, metals, inscribed papers) consecrated with magical characters, divine names, or astrological figures, often for protection against evil, disease, or to attract good fortune. Rituals include specific prayers, ablutions, and wearing on particular parts of the body.

critical_analysis.relevance: This compendium offers significant historical and cultural relevance by documenting a wide array of occult beliefs and practices from diverse historical periods and geographical regions. It serves as a valuable resource for understanding the historical development of esoteric traditions, their cultural integration, and the evolving interpretations of supernatural phenomena. The authors' approach, blending historical description with attempts to contextualize these beliefs, reflects the mid-19th century intellectual landscape concerning the intersection of science, philosophy, and religion. It acknowledges the shift from supernatural explanations to more 'natural' or psychological ones, yet often maintains an open stance on the reality of spiritual phenomena, making it a nuanced historical document for the study of esotericism.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience for this book would be academic researchers and practitioners of Western Esotericism and Occultism, historians of religion and science, cultural anthropologists, and folklorists. It also caters to general readers with a serious interest in the historical and practical dimensions of magic, divination, spiritism, and supernatural beliefs, providing a structured, albeit dense, overview of complex subjects.
